data.systemPrompt:
You are a Dashboard Builder AI assistant. Create interactive dashboards with grid layouts and three component types: charts, tables, and stat cards.

Theme: use a modern purple theme by default. Tokens: primary=#6366F1, accent=#8B5CF6, bg=#17181C, border=#2A2C33. Component container: borderRadius=12px, padding=16px (stat-card 20px). Charts must have minHeight=250px. Prefer neutral text #DDD, secondary #AAA.

Icons: always use Iconify icon names (e.g., 'lucide:users', 'lucide:dollar-sign') for stat-card 'icon' and for any column 'icon' in tables. Do not use emojis.

Component Types:
1. chart - ECharts visualizations (line, bar, pie, scatter, radar, gauge, heatmap, etc.)
2. table - Data tables with columns and rows
3. stat-card - KPI cards showing single metrics (value, label, icon, trend)

Defaults you should apply when creating components (the client also enforces these):
- Container style: bg=#17181C, border=#2A2C33, radius=12px, padding=16px (stat-card 20px)
- Chart palette: ['#6366F1','#8B5CF6','#A78BFA','#22D3EE','#F472B6','#34D399'] and minHeight 250px
- Stat card: provide icon (Iconify string), color default '#FFFFFF'

Two Ways to Provide Data:
Option A: Static Data - Provide complete data directly:
- Chart (ECharts option): {title:{text:'Sales'}, xAxis:{type:'category', data:['Mon','Tue']}, yAxis:{type:'value'}, series:[{type:'line', data:[120,200]}]}
- Table: {columns:[{key:'name',label:'Name'}], rows:[{name:'John'}]}
- Stat Card: {value:1234, label:'Total Users', icon:'lucide:users', trend:{value:12, direction:'up'}}

Option B: PostgreSQL Query - Use 'query' to fetch live data and transform via Handlebars/AlaSQL:
```javascript
{
  id:'sales_chart',
  type:'chart',
  gridArea:'main',
  title:'Monthly Sales',
  data:{},
  query:{
    sql:'SELECT month, revenue FROM sales ORDER BY month',
    handlebarsTemplate:'{"xAxis":{"type":"category","data":[{{#each data}}"{{month}}"{{#unless @last}},{{/unless}}{{/each}}]},"yAxis":{"type":"value"},"series":[{"type":"bar","data":[{{#each data}}{{revenue}}{{#unless @last}},{{/unless}}{{/each}}]}]}'
  }
}
```

Handlebars Template Examples:
For ECharts:
```
{"xAxis":{"data":[{{#each data}}"{{category}}"{{#unless @last}},{{/unless}}{{/each}}]},"series":[{"data":[{{#each data}}{{value}}{{#unless @last}},{{/unless}}{{/each}}]}]}
```
For Table:
```
{"columns":[{"key":"name","label":"Name"},{"key":"value","label":"Value"}],"rows":[{{#each data}}{"name":"{{name}}","value":{{value}}}{{#unless @last}},{{/unless}}{{/each}}]}
```
For Stat Card:
```
{"value":{{data.0.total}},"label":"Total Sales","icon":"lucide:badge-dollar-sign","trend":{"value":8.2,"direction":"up"}}
```

**Advanced Editing:**
- push: Add to arrays (e.g., add data points)
- splice: Remove/replace in arrays
- merge: Deep merge objects
- JSONPath: path='data.series[0].data'

**Workflow:**
1. Set grid layout with set_grid_layout
2. Create components (static data OR query)
3. Update with update_component

Use dark theme colors. PostgreSQL available via MCP.
data.label: system_prompt
Get Dashboard
data.toolDescription: Retrieve the complete current dashboard state including grid layout configuration and all components. Use this to understand what's currently in the dashboard before making changes.

data.label: Set Grid Layout
data.toolDescription: Configure the dashboard grid layout including columns, rows, gap, and template areas. Template areas define named grid regions where components can be placed.
data.customToolZodSchema: z.object({columns: z.string().describe('CSS grid columns like 1fr 1fr 1fr'), rows: z.string().describe('CSS grid rows like auto 1fr 1fr'), gap: z.string().describe('Gap like 16px or 1rem'), templateAreas: z.array(z.string()).describe('Grid template areas array')})

data.label: Create Component
data.toolDescription: Create a new dashboard component. Supports three types: chart (ECharts), table, or stat-card. You can provide static data OR use the query parameter to fetch live data from PostgreSQL with Handlebars/AlaSQL transformations. When a query/dataConfig is provided, this tool attempts a data fetch and returns both the raw PostgreSQL response and the final processed data (what the component renders), along with any errors.
data.customToolZodSchema: z.object({id: z.string().describe('Unique component ID like sales_chart or user_table'), type: z.enum(['chart', 'table', 'stat-card']).describe('Component type: chart (ECharts), table (data table), or stat-card (KPI card)'), gridArea: z.string().describe('Grid area name from layout'), title: z.string().optional().describe('Optional component title'), description: z.string().optional().describe('Optional description'), data: z.any().describe('Component data: ECharts options for chart, {columns, rows} for table, {value, label, trend} for stat-card. Can be empty {} if using query'), query: z.object({sql: z.string().describe('PostgreSQL query to fetch data'), handlebarsTemplate: z.string().optional().describe('Handlebars template to transform query results into component data format'), alasqlTransform: z.string().optional().describe('AlaSQL query to further transform data')}).optional().describe('Optional: Fetch data from PostgreSQL and transform with Handlebars/AlaSQL'), style: z.any().optional().describe('Custom container styles')})

data.label: Update Component
data.toolDescription: Update an existing component with advanced operations. Supports: set (replace value), push (add to array), splice (remove/replace in array), merge (deep merge objects). Use path for nested updates like data.series[0].data. If the update includes a dataConfig or query, this tool attempts a data fetch and returns both the raw PostgreSQL response and the final processed data (what the component renders), along with any errors.
data.customToolZodSchema: z.object({id: z.string().describe('Component ID to update'), path: z.string().optional().describe('JSONPath for nested updates like data.series[0].data'), updates: z.any().optional().describe('New value or data to apply'), operation: z.enum(['set', 'push', 'splice', 'merge']).optional().default('set').describe('Operation: set=replace, push=add to array, splice=remove from array, merge=deep merge'), operationParams: z.any().optional().describe('Extra params for splice: {start, deleteCount, items}')})

data.label: Remove Component
data.toolDescription: Remove a component from the dashboard by its ID. The component will be completely deleted from the dashboard state.
data.customToolZodSchema: z.object({id: z.string().describe('ID of the component to remove')})

data.label: Get Component
data.toolDescription: Retrieve a specific component's full configuration by its ID. Returns the component's type, title, data, config, and grid area placement.
data.customToolZodSchema: z.object({id: z.string().describe('ID of the component to retrieve')})

data.label: list_schemas
data.description: List all schemas in the database

data.label: get_object_details
data.description: Show detailed information about a database object

data.label: explain_query
data.description: Explains the execution plan for a SQL query, showing how the database will execute it and provides detailed cost estimates.

analyze.description: When True, actually runs the query to show real execution statistics instead of estimates. Takes longer but provides more accurate information.
analyze.title: Analyze

hypothetical_indexes.description:
A list of hypothetical indexes to simulate. Each index must be a dictionary with these keys:
    - 'table': The table name to add the index to (e.g., 'users')
    - 'columns': List of column names to include in the index (e.g., ['email'] or ['last_name', 'first_name'])
    - 'using': Optional index method (default: 'btree', other options include 'hash', 'gist', etc.)

Examples: [
    {"table": "users", "columns": ["email"], "using": "btree"},
    {"table": "orders", "columns": ["user_id", "created_at"]}
]
If there is no hypothetical index, you can pass an empty list.
hypothetical_indexes.title: Hypothetical Indexes

data.label: analyze_workload_indexes
data.description: Analyze frequently executed queries in the database and recommend optimal indexes

tools.name: list_schemas
tools.description: List all schemas in the database

tools.name: get_object_details
tools.description: Show detailed information about a database object

tools.name: explain_query
tools.description: Explains the execution plan for a SQL query, showing how the database will execute it and provides detailed cost estimates.

analyze.description: When True, actually runs the query to show real execution statistics instead of estimates. Takes longer but provides more accurate information.
analyze.title: Analyze

hypothetical_indexes.description:
A list of hypothetical indexes to simulate. Each index must be a dictionary with these keys:
    - 'table': The table name to add the index to (e.g., 'users')
    - 'columns': List of column names to include in the index (e.g., ['email'] or ['last_name', 'first_name'])
    - 'using': Optional index method (default: 'btree', other options include 'hash', 'gist', etc.)

Examples: [
    {"table": "users", "columns": ["email"], "using": "btree"},
    {"table": "orders", "columns": ["user_id", "created_at"]}
]
If there is no hypothetical index, you can pass an empty list.
hypothetical_indexes.title: Hypothetical Indexes

tools.name: analyze_workload_indexes
tools.description: Analyze frequently executed queries in the database and recommend optimal indexes

tools.name: analyze_query_indexes
tools.description: Analyze a list of (up to 10) SQL queries and recommend optimal indexes

queries.description: List of Query strings to analyze
queries.title: Queries

tools.name: analyze_db_health
tools.description:
Analyzes database health. Here are the available health checks:
- index - checks for invalid, duplicate, and bloated indexes
- connection - checks the number of connection and their utilization
- vacuum - checks vacuum health for transaction id wraparound
- sequence - checks sequences at risk of exceeding their maximum value
- replication - checks replication health including lag and slots
- buffer - checks for buffer cache hit rates for indexes and tables
- constraint - checks for invalid constraints
- all - runs all checks
You can optionally specify a single health check or a comma-separated list of health checks. The default is 'all' checks.

health_type.description: Optional. Valid values are: all, buffer, connection, constraint, index, replication, sequence, vacuum.
health_type.title: Health Type

tools.name: get_top_queries
tools.description: Reports the slowest or most resource-intensive queries using data from the 'pg_stat_statements' extension.

sort_by.description: Ranking criteria: 'total_time' for total execution time or 'mean_time' for mean execution time per call, or 'resources' for resource-intensive queries
sort_by.title: Sort By

limit.description: Number of queries to return when ranking based on mean_time or total_time
limit.title: Limit
